parts:
Show that the decimal expansion of a rational number must eventually become
periodic.

Let \(x\) be a rational number. Write it as
\[
x=\frac{p}{q}
\]
with integers \(p\) and \(q>0\). (If \(x<0\), apply the argument to \(|x|\); the sign doesn’t affect periodicity.)

It’s enough to prove the claim for the fractional part of \(x\), so assume \(0\le x<1\). We construct its decimal expansion by long division.

Define the sequence of remainders as follows:
- Let \(r_0=p\) (so \(0\le r_0<q\) after replacing \(p\) by \(p\bmod q\)).
- For each \(n\ge 0\), set
  \[
  10r_n = q a_{n+1} + r_{n+1},
  \]
  where \(a_{n+1}\in\{0,1,\dots,9\}\) and \(0\le r_{n+1}<q\).

Then the digits \(a_1,a_2,a_3,\dots\) are exactly the decimal digits of \(x\):
\[
x=0.a_1a_2a_3\cdots
\]
because at each step you are doing the usual division: multiply the current remainder by 10, take the next digit \(a_{n+1}\), and keep the new remainder \(r_{n+1}\).

Now observe the key finiteness point:

- Each remainder \(r_n\) is an integer in \(\{0,1,2,\dots,q-1\}\).
- So there are only \(q\) possible values for \(r_n\).

Therefore, among the \(q+1\) remainders
\[
r_0,r_1,\dots,r_q
\]
two must be equal (pigeonhole principle). So there exist indices \(0\le i<j\le q\) with
\[
r_i=r_j.
\]

But the division rule shows the process is *deterministic*: given a remainder \(r_n\), the next digit \(a_{n+1}\) and next remainder \(r_{n+1}\) are uniquely determined by dividing \(10r_n\) by \(q\). Hence if \(r_i=r_j\), then
\[
a_{i+1}=a_{j+1},\quad r_{i+1}=r_{j+1},
\]
and then similarly
\[
a_{i+2}=a_{j+2},\quad r_{i+2}=r_{j+2},
\]
and so on forever by induction.

So the digit block from position \(i+1\) through \(j\) repeats indefinitely:
\[
a_{i+1}a_{i+2}\cdots a_j = a_{j+1}a_{j+2}\cdots a_{2j-i},
\]
etc. That is exactly “eventually periodic.” (If the repeated remainder is \(0\), then from that point on all digits are \(0\), which is periodic too.)

Hence the decimal expansion of any rational number must eventually become periodic.

```latex
\documentclass[9pt]{extarticle}
\usepackage{graphicx,amsmath,amssymb,physics}

\begin{document}

\noindent
{\bf Proposition.}
The decimal expansion of any rational number is eventually periodic.

\bigskip

\noindent
{\bf Proof.}
Let \(x\) be a rational number. Then
\[
x=\frac{p}{q}
\]
for some integers \(p\) and \(q>0\). The sign of \(x\) does not affect periodicity, so we may assume without loss of generality that \(x\ge 0\). Moreover, by separating the integer part, it suffices to consider the case \(0\le x<1\).

\medskip

We generate the decimal expansion of \(x\) by the standard long-division algorithm. Set
\[
r_0 = p \bmod q,
\]
so that \(0 \le r_0 < q\). For each \(n \ge 0\), define integers \(a_{n+1}\in\{0,1,\dots,9\}\) and \(r_{n+1}\) by
\[
10r_n = q a_{n+1} + r_{n+1}, \qquad 0 \le r_{n+1} < q.
\]
Then
\[
x = 0.a_1 a_2 a_3 \cdots,
\]
and the digits \(a_1,a_2,\dots\) are precisely the decimal digits of \(x\).

\medskip

Each remainder \(r_n\) is an integer lying in the finite set
\[
\{0,1,2,\dots,q-1\},
\]
which contains only \(q\) elements. Therefore, among the \(q+1\) remainders
\[
r_0,r_1,\dots,r_q
\]
there must exist indices \(0\le i<j\le q\) such that
\[
r_i = r_j,
\]
by the pigeonhole principle.

\medskip

The division process is deterministic: given a remainder \(r_n\), the next digit \(a_{n+1}\) and next remainder \(r_{n+1}\) are uniquely determined by dividing \(10r_n\) by \(q\). Hence, if \(r_i=r_j\), then
\[
a_{i+1}=a_{j+1} \quad \text{and} \quad r_{i+1}=r_{j+1}.
\]
Repeating this argument inductively shows that
\[
a_{i+k}=a_{j+k} \quad \text{for all } k\ge 1.
\]

\medskip

Thus the block of digits
\[
a_{i+1}a_{i+2}\cdots a_j
\]
repeats indefinitely, and the decimal expansion of \(x\) is eventually periodic. If the repeated remainder is \(0\), then all subsequent digits are \(0\), which is a special case of periodicity.

\medskip

This completes the proof.
\hfill\(\Box\)

\end{document}
```
